content: The MORE Act of 2008 terminates prohibitions on expenditures for offshore oil and gas leasing activities on the Outer Continental Shelf. All federal laws prohibiting such expenditures are revoked, allowing for exploration, development, and production of oil and natural gas in these areas. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to require state approval for oil and gas leasing within 25 miles of a state's coastline. Repeal of state approval laws will not affect this requirement. Additionally, the MORE Act of 2008 removes prohibitions on expenditures for offshore oil and gas leasing activities. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to require state approval for oil and gas leasing within 25 miles of a state's coastline. Royalties from qualified oil and gas leases on submerged lands within state boundaries will be divided, with 25 percent going to the Treasury. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to require state approval for oil and gas leasing within 25 miles of a state's coastline. Royalties from qualified oil and gas leases on submerged lands within state boundaries will be divided, with 10% going to the Treasury and 90% to the producing States. The amendment to the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act requires state approval for oil and gas leasing within 25 miles of a state's coastline. Royalties from qualified leases on submerged lands within state boundaries will be divided, with a percentage equivalent to the surface acreage within seaward boundaries going to the respective state. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act requires state approval for oil and gas leasing within 25 miles of a state's coastline. Royalties from qualified leases on submerged lands within state boundaries will be divided based on the surface acreage within seaward boundaries going to the respective state. The term 'adjacent zone' refers to the portion of the outer Continental Shelf where programs, plans, lease sales, or activities are conducted under the Act. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act requires state approval for oil and gas leasing within 25 miles of a state's coastline. The Act designates the portion of the outer Continental Shelf for which the laws of a particular adjacent State apply. The term 'producing State' refers to an Adjacent State with leased tracts that generate royalties. The term 'State' includes Puerto Rico and other U.S. territories. A 'qualified oil and gas lease' is a lease under this Act. The Maximize Offshore Resource Exploration Act of 2008 defines a 'qualified oil and gas lease' as a lease authorizing oil and natural gas development. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to establish State Seaward Boundaries. The Maximize Offshore Resource Exploration Act of 2008 defines a 'qualified oil and gas lease' as a lease authorizing oil and natural gas development. It also establishes State Seaward Boundaries for Outer Continental Shelf regions. Maps for each region are dated September 2005 and on file in the Office of the Director, Minerals Management Service. The Gulf of Mexico Energy Security Act of 2006 is exempt from certain provisions regarding outer Continental Shelf revenues.
